relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  

Lock 61 is the 4th of the 13 upper locks that was constructed as a “composite lock”, or a lock made with more than one material. It is made of kyanized (treated) wood and uncut stone. The composite stone was quarried from nearby Twigg Hollow and was brought here by horse-drawn rail cars. The poor-quality materials used to make this lock concerned the Canal Company, but lack of funds initially yielded no alternatives. More stone was eventually brought in from Town Hill nine miles away and much of the wood lining was replaced by concrete.

On the other side of the lock is a bypass flume that allowed water to bypass the lock to water the level below. Remains of the lockhouse’s stone foundation can be found across from the lock, near the towpath.
audioDescription: (137 words) Lock 61 is located along the towpath in Oldtown, Maryland. From Bonds Landing Road, turn right onto the towpath to head upstream, and walk 3.1 miles. On your right is the lock. It is about 5 feet from the towpath and runs parallel to it. The lock is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. The upstream and downstream wooden lock gates are missing. A wooden bridge crosses over the upstream section of the lock. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. Crossing the bridge puts you in between the lock and a bypass flume. Across from the lock, on the other side of the towpath, are the remains of the lockhouse foundation. It is about 15 feet from the towpath and only a few stones remain. End of description.

title: C&O Canal Lock 62

images.altText: A look through a grass covered lock with a foot bridge connecting the stone lock walls.
images.title: Lock 62
images.caption: Lock 62

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about 8 feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  

Lock 62 is the 5th of the 13 upper locks that was constructed as a “composite lock”, or a lock made with more than one material. It is made of kyanized (treated) wood and uncut stone. Some wood lining remains along the rock wall, while several other sections have been replaced by concrete. Although majority of the locks lifted and lowered boats about 8 feet, this lock had a 10-foot lift.

On the other side of the lock is a bypass flume that allowed water to bypass the lock to water the level below. Adjacent to the towpath is the concrete foundation of the lockhouse.
audioDescription: (328 words) Lock 62 is located along the towpath in Oldtown, Maryland. To access it, go to the Paw Paw Tunnel Drive-in Campground parking area off of MD-51. From the parking lot is a short, 50-foot path with a slight incline that leads up to the towpath. Once on the gravel towpath, make a right to head downstream towards Lock 62. Lock 62 is about 1.9 miles down the towpath but at about a half a mile, you will approach Paw Paw Tunnel. It is 3,118 feet long with wooden railings on the left side and the wall of the tunnel on the right. These are the original railings and contain rope burns from when the canal boats were pulled through the tunnel by mules. At the downstream exit of the tunnel is a wooden boardwalk with railings on the left side. Stay on this for about 0.15 of a mile until getting back on the gravel section of the towpath. Head down another 0.9 of a mile and the lock will be to your left. The lock is about 2 feet from the towpath and runs parallel to it. The lock is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. Two large walls of stone and treated wood make up the sides of the lock. The upstream and downstream wooden lock gates are missing. A wooden bridge crosses over the upstream section of the lock. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. Crossing the bridge puts you in a grassy area between the lock and a bypass flume. Across from the lock, on the other side of the towpath are the remains of the stone foundation of the lockhouse. It is about 5 feet away from the towpath. On the downstream side of the foundation is a water pump with potable water and about 100 feet further downstream is a chemical toilet about 5 feet from the towpath on the right. End of description.

title: C&O Canal Lock 63

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  

Lock 63 1/3 is the 6th of the upper 13 locks that was constructed as a “composite lock”, or a lock made with more than one material. It is made of kyanized (treated) wood and uncut stone. Some of the lock was eventually replaced with concrete. 

On the other side of the lock is a bypass flume that allowed water to bypass the lock to water the level below.

The odd numbering of this lock is a result of Lock 65 never being built. The Canal Company eliminated Lock 65 to reduce costs and used the fractions as documentation of the gap in the lift lock numbering system, while still allowing the upstream lock numbers to remain. Locks 62, 63 1/3, 64 2/3, and 66 have a 10’ lift to make up for the elimination.

There are no lockhouse remains at this location.

From the parking lot is a short, 50-foot path, with a slight incline that leads up to the towpath. Once on the gravel towpath, turn right to head downstream towards Lock 63 1/3. Lock 63 1/3 is about 1.6 miles down the towpath but at about a half a mile, you will approach Paw Paw Tunnel. It is 3,118 feet long with wooden railings on the left side and the wall of the tunnel on the right. These are the original railings and contain rope burns from when the canal boats were being pulled through the tunnel by mules. At the downstream exit of the tunnel is a wooden boardwalk with railings on the left side. Stay on this for about 0.15 of a mile until getting back on the gravel section of the towpath. Head down another 0.6 miles and the lock will be to your left. The lock is about 5 feet from the towpath and runs parallel to it. The lock is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. Two large walls of stone, concrete, and treated wood make up the sides of the lock. The upstream and downstream wooden lock gates are missing. A wooden bridge crosses over the upstream section of the lock. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. Crossing the bridge puts you in a grassy area between the lock and a bypass flume. End of description.

Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  


Lock 64 2/3 is the 7th of the 13 locks that was constructed as a “composite lock”, or a lock made with more than one material. On the other side of the lock is a bypass flume that allowed water to bypass the lock to water the level below.

Locks 62, 63 1/3, 64 2/3, and 66 have a 10’ lift to make up for the elimination.

Remnants of a lockhouse sits about 10’ above the towpath on a small plateau.

Head down another 0.5 miles and the lock will be to your left. The lock is about 5 feet from the towpath and runs parallel to it. The lock is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. Two large walls of stone, concrete, and treated wood make up the sides of the lock. The upstream and downstream wooden lock gates are missing. A wooden bridge crosses over the upstream section of the lock. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. Crossing the bridge puts you in a grassy area between the lock and where the bypass flume used to be. Across from the lock, on the other side of the towpath on a small plateau, are a few stones left from the foundation of the lockhouse. They are about 5 feet from the towpath across from the upstream section of the lock. End of description.

bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.

A carpenter shop used to exist here but burned down in the 1960s. Only a few stones from the foundation of the lockhouse remain.

Lock 66 is about 1.4 miles down the towpath but at about a half a mile, you will approach Paw Paw Tunnel. At the downstream exit of the tunnel is a wooden boardwalk with railings on the left side. Stay on this for about 0.15 of a mile until getting back on the gravel section of the towpath. Head down another 0.4 miles and the lock will be to your left. The lock is about 5 feet from the towpath and runs parallel to it. The lock is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. Two large walls of stone and concrete make up the sides of the lock. The upstream and downstream wooden lock gates are missing. A wooden bridge crosses over the upstream section of the lock. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. Crossing the bridge puts you in a grassy area between the lock and where the bypass flume used to be. Across from the lock, on the other side of the towpath are a few stones left from the foundation of the lockhouse. They are about 15 feet away from the towpath, across from the upstream section of the lock. End of description.

title: C&O Canal Lock 67

images.altText: Green algae covers the water running through lock 67.
images.title: Lock 67
images.caption: Lock 67

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  

Lock 67, also known as Darkey’s Lock, is 9th of the upper 13 locks that was constructed as a “composite lock”, or a lock made with more than one material. It is made of kyanized (treated) wood and uncut stone. However, the use of wood created many problems. The wood lining in many of these locks were replaced by concrete from 1891–1924. On the other side of the lock is a bypass flume that allowed water to bypass the lock to water the level below.

The name of the lock comes from its long-time locktender Hughey Darkey. Only the foundation of the lockhouse remains and is partly underground.
audioDescription: (180 words) Lock 67 is located along the towpath in Oldtown, Maryland. To access it, go to the Town Creek Aqueduct parking area. Through the gates is a small gravel path with a slight decline that veers to the left after about 30 feet. Go straight about 30 more feet to get to the gravel towpath. Turn left to head downstream and walk about half a mile. Lock 67 is located on the left, about 5 feet from the towpath, and runs parallel to it. The lock is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. Two large walls of stone, treated wood, and concrete make up the sides of the lock. The upstream and downstream wooden lock gates are missing. Across from the middle of the lock, on the other side of the towpath, about 5 feet away, are the remains of the lockhouse. Only a few stones from the lockhouse’s foundation are still present and are partly underground. There is a depression inside of the stone foundation outline where the land drops in a few feet. End of description.

title: C&O Canal Lock 68

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  

Lock 68, also known as Crabtree’s Lock, was completed in late 1849 or early 1850. It is the 10th of the upper 13 locks that was constructed as a “composite lock”, or a lock made with more than one material. It is made of kyanized (treated) wood and uncut stone. The use of wood created many problems and some sections eventually had to be replaced with concrete. On the other side of the lock is a bypass flume that allowed water to bypass the lock to water the level below.

The nickname of the lock comes from two generations of the Crabtree family serving as locktenders in the two-and-a-half story lockhouse that is adjacent to the lock.

At this site, there is also an old steel and wooden bridge that once connected Rt. 51 to a ferry that crossed the Potomac River to South Branch Depot (later known as French Station on the B&O, and then, just South Branch) in West Virginia. The bridge was rebuilt in 1865 and again in 1918. The original was a wood pivot bridge that was destroyed during the Civil War. The current bridge follows a Warren Truss design.

On the other side of the lock is the Potomac Forks Hiker-Biker Campsite.
audioDescription: (314 words) Lock 68 is located along the towpath in Oldtown, Maryland. To access it, go to the Town Creek Aqueduct parking area. Through the gates is a small gravel path with a slight decline that veers to the left after about 30 feet. Go straight about 30 more feet to get to the gravel towpath. Turn right to head upstream and walk about 2 miles to get to Lock 68. It will be on your right. Just before Lock 68, you will go under an old steel bridge. A few feet past the bridge is a 10-foot wide grassy berm that runs along the downstream end of the lock and leads to a 15-foot wide grassy strip in between the lock and the bypass flume. The lock is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. Two large walls of stone, treated wood, and concrete make up the sides of the lock. A wooden bridge crosses over the upstream section of the lock. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. Crossing the bridge from the towpath also puts you in the 15-foot wide grassy strip in between the lock and the bypass flume. Straight across from the wooden bridge, is another wooden bridge with railings that passes over the bypass flume. On the other side is a camping area. There is a small dirt path that veers to the left for about 15 feet, that then develops into a straighter path that runs parallel to the canal. Straight ahead, about 30 feet, is a picnic table with a small grill right behind it. About 30 feet further is a well pump with potable water. From the towpath, the lock sits about 5 feet away. On the other side of the towpath is a two-and-a-half story white frame lockhouse that is about 3 feet from the towpath. End of description.

title: C&O Canal Lock 69

images.altText: Looking down a water filled lock with two parallel stone walls on the right and left.
images.title: Lock 69
images.caption: Lock 69

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  

Lock 69, also known as Twigg’s Lock, was completed in late 1849 to early 1850. It is the 11th of the upper 13 locks that was constructed as a “composite lock”, or a lock made with more than one material. It is made of kyanized (treated) wood and uncut stone. However, the use of wood created many problems. The wood lining in many of these locks were replaced by concrete from 1891–1924. A stop gate was placed on the upstream end of the lock to keep water in the canal as part of the Battie Mixon fishing area. On the other side of the lock is a bypass flume that allowed water to bypass the lock to water the level below.

The name of the lock comes from the family that used to serve as locktenders. No remnants of the lockhouse remain. 

Locks 69-71 are considered as the Oldtown Locks. This watered section of the canal is part of the Battie Mixon fishing area.
audioDescription: (387 words) Lock 69 is located in Oldtown, MD. To access it, go to the parking lot off of Green Spring Road SE. The parking lot is laid out as a circle, but the parking spots don’t start until about 100 feet in from the turn off from Green Spring Road. In the first row of parking spots, on the side closest to the parking entrance within the circle, is a park bulletin board. Just to the left, is a little dirt walkway with a slight incline that veers to the left. This little 20-foot path leads to a grassy area along a watered section of the canal. Once on flat surface, walk about 20 feet forward and the canal will be about 30 feet away from your right. About 50 feet straight ahead is Lock 70. There is a small, 15-foot wooden bridge that crosses over the upstream section of the lock. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. Once across the bridge, walk about 5 more feet to get to the gravel towpath. Turn left to head downstream. About 70 feet ahead are gates blocking vehicles from entering the towpath from Green Spring Road with enough space for pedestrians and cyclist to pass through. After walking past these, about 10 feet away is Green Spring Road. Once you cross the road, there will be another set of gates blocking vehicles from entering the towpath. Go straight through and head down about a quarter of a mile. On the left, about 5 feet from the towpath, is the lock, which runs parallel to the towpath. It is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. Two large walls of stone, treated wood, and concrete make up the sides of the lock. The upstream and downstream wooden lock gates are missing. A wooden bridge crosses over the downstream section of the lock. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. Crossing the bridge puts you in a 15-foot wide grassy area between the lock and a bypass flume. The bypass flume runs from a basin above the lock and discharges through a sloping wall. A stop gate was placed on the upstream end of the lock to keep water in the canal. No remnants of the lockhouse remain. End of description.

audioDescription: (110 words) Lock 7 is located along the towpath in Cabin John, MD. It can be accessed from a small parking lot off of the Clara Barton Parkway. From the Lock 7 parking lot, follow the gravel path down the hill approximately 200 feet. You’ll pass the lock house on your left, and cross a short wooden bridge over a wet area. The train turns left and continues another 100 feet and to arrive at the lock. A pedestrian access bridge crosses the lock, with railings along both sides. The dirt towpath is across the lock bridge, with south being to the left and north being to the right. End of Description.

bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  

Lock 70 is 12th of the upper 13 locks that was constructed as a “composite lock”, or a lock made with more than one material. It was made of kyanized (treated) wood and uncut stone. It was completed in late 1849 or 1850, but after a fire in 1906, the lock was rebuilt.

Locks 69-71 are considered as the Oldtown Locks. This watered section of the canal is part of the Battie Mixon fishing area.

Adjacent to the lock, is a two-story white frame lockhouse. During the summer, the Lockhouse is open on Saturday and Sunday afternoons where visitors can view a small exhibit on Oldtown’s history.
audioDescription: (260 words) Lock 70 is located in Oldtown, Maryland. To access it, go to the parking lot off of Green Spring Road SE. The parking lot is laid out as a circle, but the parking spots don’t start until about 100 feet in from the turn off from Green Spring Road. In the first row of parking spots, on the side closest to the parking entrance within the circle, is a park bulletin board. Just to the left, is a little dirt walkway with a slight incline that veers to the left. This little 20-foot path leads to a grassy area along a watered section of the canal. Once on flat surface, walk about 20 feet forward and the canal will be about 30 feet away from your right. About 50 feet straight ahead is Lock 70. It is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. Two large walls of stone, treated wood, and concrete make up the sides of the lock. The upstream and downstream wooden lock gates are missing. There is a stop gate at the upstream end of the lock to keep water within the basin to form another pool for the Battie Mixon fishing area. There is a small, 15-foot wooden bridge that crosses over the upstream section of the lock. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. Once across the bridge, walk about 5 more feet to get to the gravel towpath. Turn right to head upstream and about 20 feet to your left is a two-story white frame lockhouse.

bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  

Lock 71 is the last of the upper 13 locks that was constructed as a “composite lock”, or a lock made with more than one material. It is made of kyanized (treated) wood and uncut stone. However, the use of wood created many problems. The wood lining in many of these locks were replaced by concrete from 1891–1924. Bolts that were used to hold the wooden sheathing are still in place.

Locks 69-71 are considered as the Oldtown Locks and were completed in late 1849 or early 1850. Adjacent to the lock is a white, two-and-a-half story lockhouse.
audioDescription: (330 words) Lock 71 is located in Oldtown, Maryland. To access it, go to the parking lot off of Green Spring Road SE. The parking lot is laid out as a circle, but the parking spots don’t start until about 100 feet in from the turn off from Green Spring Road. In the first row of parking spots, on the side closest to the parking entrance within the circle, is a park bulletin board. Just to the left, is a little dirt walkway with a slight incline that veers to the left. This little 20-foot path leads to a grassy area along a watered section of the canal. Once on flat surface, walk about 20 feet forward and the canal will be about 30 feet away from your right. About 50 feet straight ahead is Lock 70. There is a small, 15-foot wooden bridge that crosses over the upstream section of the lock. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. Once across the bridge, walk about 5 more feet to get to the gravel towpath. Turn right to head upstream and walk 0.34 of a mile. Lock 71 will be to your right. It is about 5 feet from the towpath and runs parallel to it. The lock is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. Two large walls of stone, treated wood, and concrete make up the sides of the lock. The upstream and downstream wooden lock gates are missing. A wooden bridge crosses over the upstream section of the lock. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. Crossing the bridge puts you on the other side of the lock on a grassy berm with the remnants of a bypass flume a few feet from the downstream edge of the lock. Across from the lock, on the other side of the towpath, is a two-and-a-half story white framed lockhouse. It is about 10 feet away from the towpath. End of description.

title: C&O Canal Lock 72

images.altText: A look down a bush filled lock with two lock walls stretching up on the right and left.
images.title: Lock 72
images.caption: Lock 72

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  

Lock 72 is made from limestone that was quarried nearby and was completed in 1841. The limestone used to build this Lock, and Locks 73 – 75, were described as “beautiful, of good quality, and in great abundance”. This lock uses a “slope wall” design at the lower end of the wing wall and bypass flume, and has a 9’ lift.

During the Canal Days, this lock and area was referred to as the “Ten Mile Lock” because it is almost exactly 10 miles from Cumberland.

Adjacent to the lock is a two-and-a-half story lockhouse.
audioDescription: (188 words) Lock 72 is located in Cumberland, Maryland. To access it, go to the parking area for Lock 74 off of River Road SE. The towpath access points have gates blocking vehicles from entering the towpath but provide enough space for pedestrians and cyclists to pass through. Head downstream about 1 mile and to your left is Lock 72. It is about 5 feet from the towpath and runs parallel to it. The lock is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. Two limestone brick walls make up the sides of the lock. The upstream and downstream wooden lock gates are missing. A wooden bridge crosses in the middle section of the lock. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. Crossing the bridge puts you on the other side of the lock where the bypass flume used to be. Some of the limestone remnants of the bypass flume remain adjacent to the downstream end of the lock. Across from the lock, on the other side of the towpath, about 10 feet away, is a two-and-a-half story, white frame lockhouse. End of description.

title: C&O Canal Lock 73

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  

Lock 73 is the first of 3 in North Branch and was completed in 1840 but was rebuilt in 1869. It is made of limestone from Evitts Creek Quarry and has a 9’ lift. On the other side of the lock is a bypass flume that allowed water to bypass the lock to water the level below. There are no remnants of a lockhouse at this site.

During the Canal Days, this area was known as “The Narrows” because the canal, highway, and railroad all passed through this tight space between the Potomac River, Nicolas Ridge, and Irons Mountain.
audioDescription: (238 words) Lock 73 is located in Cumberland, Maryland. To access it, go to the parking area for Lock 74 off of River Road SE. The towpath access points have gates blocking vehicles from entering the towpath but provide enough space for pedestrians and cyclists to pass through. Head downstream about 0.1 of a mile and to your left is Lock 73. It is about 5 feet from the towpath and runs parallel to it. The lock is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. Two limestone brick walls make up the sides of the lock. The upstream and downstream wooden lock gates are missing. On the other side of the lock is the bypass flume. This location is also set up as a hiker-biker camping area. Across from the downstream section of the lock, on the other side of the towpath, is a water pump with potable water. It is about 5 feet from the towpath. About 30 more feet downstream on the towpath leads you in front of the Irons Mountain Hiker Biker Campsite sign. About 10 feet behind it is a grill. About 30 feet past the grill is a picnic table next to the river. Further down the towpath, about 20 more feet from the Hiker-biker sign, is a chemical toilet. It is about 20 feet from the towpath. There are no remnants of a lockhouse at this site. End of description.

title: C&O Canal Lock 74

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  

Lock 74 is 2nd of the 3 locks in North Branch and was completed in 1841 but was rebuilt in 1869. It is made of limestone from Evitts Creek Quarry and has a 10’ lift. On the other side of the lock is a bypass flume that allowed water to bypass the lock to water the level below.

The lockhouse that once stood here burned in 1974.
audioDescription: (144 words) Lock 74 is located in Cumberland, Maryland. To access it, go to the parking area for this lock off of River Road SE. Access the towpath from either side of the road, as the lock sites underneath of the River Road bridge. The towpath access points have gates blocking vehicles from entering the towpath but provide enough space for pedestrians and cyclists to pass through. The lock is about 5 feet away from the towpath and runs adjacent to it. The lock is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. Two limestone brick walls make up the sides of the lock. The upstream and downstream wooden lock gates are missing. On the other side of the downstream section of the lock are remnants of a bypass flume. There are no remnants of a lockhouse at this site. End of description.

title: C&O Canal Lock 75

images.altText: A tall water filled lock sits on the right with the towpath and lockhouse on the left.
images.title: Lock 75
images.caption: Lock 75

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  

This is the last lift lock in North Branch and on the C&O Canal. It has a lift of 10’ (609.193’ above the first lock located in Georgetown). The original limestone used to build this lock, as well as Locks 72 – 74, had been described as “beautiful, of good quality, and in great abundance”. The lock was rebuilt in 1869 meeting the 1836 specifications. New gates were installed at the downstream end in the 1990s. On the other side of the lock is a bypass flume that allowed water to bypass the lock to water the level below.

Adjacent to the lock is a two-story log lockhouse that was reconstructed in 1978. During the summer, the lockhouse is open to view on the weekends, staff permitting.
audioDescription: (216 words) Lock 75 is located in Cumberland, Maryland. To access it, go to the parking area for this lock off of Pittsburgh Plate Glass Road SE. From the parking area, there is a path in between the wooden fences. Head straight down this path towards the canal and walk about 200 feet. You will go up a slight incline that leads to a wooden bridge that crosses over a bypass flume. There are wooden railings on both sides of the bridge. This leads you on top of the stone structure of the lock. About 7 feet further is another wooden bridge with railings that crosses over the lock. Crossing this bridge brings you about 5 feet away from the gravel towpath at the upstream end of the lock. The lock runs parallel to the towpath and is about 95 feet long, 15 feet wide, and 16 feet deep. Two limestone brick walls make up the sides of the lock. The downstream wooden lock gates are still intact. Turn left on the towpath to head downstream and about 30 feet, on the other side of the towpath on the right, is a white, two-story log lockhouse. About100 feet downstream from the lockhouse is a chemical toilet, on the right, about 10 feet from the towpath. End of description.

Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  
 
Locks 8 through 14 are known as Seven Locks. These seven locks are all close together over a 1.25-mile stretch.
audioDescription: (110 words) Lock 8 is located along the towpath in Cabin John, MD. It can be accessed from a small parking lot off of the Clara Barton Parkway. From the Lock 8 parking lot, hike the dirt and root-filled trail down the steep embankment, approximately 200 feet. Trail will intersect another trail/road, stay left. Cross a small wooden bridge and then pass the lock house on your left. Walk another 50 feet and arrive at the lock. A pedestrian access bridge crosses the lock, with railings along both sides. The dirt towpath is across the lock bridge, with south being to the left and north being to the right. End of Description.

bodyText:
Along the 184.5 miles of the canal are 74 lift locks. These locks were put into place to help boats overcome the 605-foot elevation change between Georgetown and Cumberland. The C&O Canal is like a staircase, canal boats traveled along the flat sections and used the locks to take a “step up or down” about eight feet. The locks typically had hand-operated miter gates that were simple and followed Leonardo da Vinci’s original 1485 design. Entering the lock was the most demanding part of canalling.  At this lock, drop gates replaced the miter gates to speed up the process of going through the lock.
 
Locks 8 through 14 are known as Seven Locks. These seven locks are all close together over a 1.25-mile stretch.
audioDescription: (88 words) Lock 9 is located along the towpath in Cabin John, MD. It can be accessed from a small parking lot at Lock 10 and walking the towpath. From the Lock 10 parking lot, follow the paved road down the hill approximately 100 feet and cross the bridge across lock 10. Turn left and walk 1/10ths of a mile on the towpath. The lock sits in the ground parallel to the towpath. Two stone walls create the lock chamber. The chamber is approximately 90 feet long. End of Description.

title: C&O Canal Lockhouse 10 Canal Quarters

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park

bodyText: The life of a lockkeeper was hard work. The lockkeeper was expected to move boats through the lock at all hours, every day of the week. While not quite the same today, you can enjoy the canal in a unique way by spending a night in this lockhouse. Along the canal there are seven Canal Quarters that guests can stay in. Each lockhouse has furniture and accessories from a different time period, and each tells a different story about the development of the C&O Canal. Step back in time and imagine what life was like 60, 90, or 150 years ago! Find out more information and reserve your stay with the C&O Canal Trust.

bodyText: The life of a lockkeeper was hard work. The lockkeeper was expected to move boats through the lock at all hours, every day of the week. While not quite the same today, you can enjoy the canal in a unique way by spending a night in this lockhouse. Along the canal there are seven Canal Quarters that guests can stay in. Each lockhouse has furniture and accessories from a different time period, and each tells a different story about the development of the C&O Canal. Step back in time and imagine what life was like 60, 90, or 150 years ago! Find out more information and reserve your stay with the C&O Canal Trust.
audioDescription: (136 words) Lockhouse 25 is located on Edwards Ferry Road in Poolesville, Maryland. From the parking lot, walk back along Edwards Ferry Road the way you drove in. As you walk, you will pass the ruins of Jarboe’s Store on your right. Lockhouse 25 is on the towpath which intersects with Edwards Ferry Road about 100 feet from the parking lot. Once you walk 100 feet, look for the dirt towpath on your left. If you reach the wooden bridge that spans lock 25 you have gone too far. The lockhouse will be 100 down the towpath on your left. The rectangular structure is made of bricks which are painted white. The door sits in the center of the wall facing you and is framed by two shuttered windows. The roof has two chimneys, one on each end.

audioDescription: (176 words) Lockhouse 28 is located along the towpath in Jefferson, Maryland. To get to the lockhouse start at the Point of Rocks parking lot. Head to the northwestern edge of the lot to find the short gravel access path that leads to the towpath. Turn left onto the towpath from the access path. After eight tenths of a mile the lockhouse with appear on the left about 10 feet from the towpath. The lockhouse has a rectangular base with an A frame roof. The structure is made of bricks that have been painted white. The paint is chipping away leaving yellow age makes behind. While standing on the towpath the side of the house faces you. It has a white door on the right with three green shuttered windows, one to the left of the door and two above. To the left of the house, a modern access ramp leads up the front door. Approximately 10 feet to the left of the ramp sits a picnic table. On the other side of the towpath is lock 28.

title: C&O Canal Lockhouse 29 (Lander)

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park

bodyText: The life of a lockkeeper was hard work! The lockkeeper was expected to move boats through the lock at all hours, every day of the week. In exchange, they received a rent-free house, approximately $150 a year (increasing over the years), and an acre of land for a garden and livestock. Large families were often preferred for these positions because they could manage multiple locks at a time with a small increase in pay.
audioDescription: (136 words) Lockhouse 29 is located along the towpath in Jefferson, Maryland. From the Lock 29 (Lander) parking lot, head to the Northwestern edge of the lot to reach the road you drove in on. On the opposite side of the road, in front of you, sits the lockhouse. The lockhouse has a rectangular base with an A frame roof. The structure is made of bricks that have been painted white. The side of the house, which faces the parking lot, has three green shuttered windows, two on the top level and one on the bottom. The front of the house has a small porch over the door and a window to the right of it. There are white fences on both the front and back of the house. Lock 29 is a little further down the road.

bodyText: The life of a lockkeeper was hard work! The lockkeeper was expected to move boats through the lock at all hours, every day of the week. In exchange, they received a rent-free house, approximately $150 a year (increasing over the years), and an acre of land for a garden and livestock. Large families were often preferred for these positions because they could manage multiple locks at a time with a small increase in pay.
audioDescription: (263 words) Lockhouse 44 is located on the towpath in Williamsport, Maryland. From the Lock 44 parking lot head to the Southwest corner of the lot. A gravel access trail leaves from the corner of the lot toward lock 44 and lockhouse 44. Follow it South for 190 feet. On your right will be a set of two locks parallel to each other. Two wooden pedestrian bridges span the locks to the towpath and the lockhouse on the other side. The bridges have wooden railings. After going over the first bridge continue straight for about 10 feet to reach the second bridge. About five feet past the second bridge is the towpath, which is parallel to the locks. The lock walls are made of stone blocks. Four walls create two lock chambers that are about ten feet deep each. At the upstream and downstream entrance to the locks are wooden swing gates. Opposite the lock, on the other side of the towpath is lockhouse 44. The house sits parallel to the towpath with the front facing you. The house has two sections. A two-story section with a rectangular base and a one-story section with a square base. The two sections are connected, with the one-story section on the left and the two-story section on the right. The larger, two-story section has the front door and nine windows, two windows on either side of the door and five above. A small over hang sits over the front door. The smaller, one-story section has a door and a window. The building is made of white painted planks.

audioDescription: (187 words) Lockhouse 48 is located near the towpath in Clear Spring, Maryland. From the Four Lock parking area head to the northern most corner of the lot. This is where the entrance road meets the parking lot. Follow the entrance road about two tenths of a mile, until on the left a gravel access trail splits from the road. Follow the access trail for about one tenth of a mile and turn left onto the towpath. Lock 48 and lockhouse 48 are about 40 feet up the towpath on the right. The lock sits about eight feet from the towpath and runs parallel to it. In the distance, beyond the lock and a road, sits lockhouse 48. The house has a rectangular base and is three-stories tall. The structure is made of red bricks. The bottom story is painted white, while the top two-stories are unpainted. The front porch and door sit on the second story, with a small staircase leading up to them. There is a window on either side of the door and three above it. The roof is an A frame roof with two chimneys.

title: C&O Canal Mile 0
listingDescription: From this point, hikers and bikers can state unequivocally that they have ended - or are just starting- their full trip on the C&O Canal towpath. The towpath follows along the canal for 184.5 miles to the Cumberland, MD terminus. Many bikers begin in Pittsburgh and travel the Great Allegheny Passage (GAP) trail to Cumberland and then follow the towpath to here for a total trip of 333 miles.If you are a through biker or hiker reaching the end of your journey, Congratulations!!

images.altText: A grey miller with the words mile zero.
images.title: C&O Canal Mile 0
images.caption: C&O Canal Mile 0

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
From this point, hikers and bikers can state unequivocally that they have ended - or are just starting- their full trip on the C&O Canal towpath. The towpath follows along the canal for 184.5 miles to the Cumberland, MD terminus. Many bikers begin in Pittsburgh and travel the Great Allegheny Passage (GAP) trail to Cumberland and then follow the towpath to here for a total trip of 333 miles.

If you are a through biker or hiker reaching the end of your journey, Congratulations!! If you are starting your journey, have a great trip!
audioDescription:
(237 words)
The C&O Canal Mile 0 is located at the end of a peninsula formed by the Potomac River and Rock Creek in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, D.C.
From the intersection of Virginia Avenue and Rock Creek Parkway, NW travel west on Virginia avenue into a parking lot. Continue west through the parking lot, which will turn into a walkway bridge of about ninety feet over Rock Creek. Follow the path about eighty feet, at which point it will turn left. The Potomac River now will be on the right. Continue south and travel two hundred feet, past a cement landing at Thompson Boat Center on the left. Proceed through this area onto a gravel patch and continue another fifty feet. At this point the Potomac River edge will be approaching. Turn left and proceed about seventy feet along a two-foot wide gravel path. The path will turn right, go across a thirty-foot pedestrian bridge, turn slightly right again, and after thirty more feet you will be at the C&O Canal Mile 0 marker.
The three-foot tall, one-square-foot monolith is inscribed on its north face:
Mile
-0-
It sits on a patch of dirt at the end of the peninsula. Rock Creek feeds from the north around the point and flows into the Potomac River ten feet to the south. The wood beam ruins of an old canal lock hang in the water from the lands edge.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: C&O Canal Mile 4
listingDescription: This is the fourth mile marker on the C&O Canal - only 178.5 miles to go until Cumberland!

images.altText: A mile marker sits next to the towpath and marks the forth mile of the C&O Canal
images.title: Mile 4 of the C & O Canal
images.caption: Mile 4 of the C & O Canal

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText: This is the fourth mile marker on the C&O Canal - only 178.5 miles to go until Cumberland!
audioDescription:
(168 words)
The C&O Canal Mile 4 marker is located along the C&O Canal towpath, about three hundred twenty yards south of Chain Bridge.
The marker sits of the west side of the towpath, about one foot off the dirt path. Mile 4 is a red cement obelisk, about two feet tall and three inches wide on each side. On the top of its front face is inscribed in white letters: "Mile 4." A slightly upward arching white line runs just below.
To the left of the marker is a three-foot tall, one-foot wide, two-inch thick white granite marker with rounded top. A faded etching across the face reads:
Miles to W. C.
The markers are bordered by lush forest behind them to the west. On the opposite side of the towpath a grassy patch of about two feet leads to the canal. About fifty feet south on the path is a wooden side path that arches out on the west side of the path for about four hundred feet.
END OF DESCRIPTION

Inlet Lock 1, which is at Lift Lock 5 over the Washington, DC boundary in Maryland, feeds the Georgetown section. Waste Weirs (a gate in the side of the canal) and the lift lock gates can be used used to adjust levels. There are also spillways along the canal, which are also referred to as "mule drinks" that operate l

images.altText: A paved path sits next to a wooden board walk.
images.title: C & O Canal Mule drink and overflow
images.caption: C & O Canal Mule drink and overflow

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText: Managing water levels both during normal canal operations and during floods was and still is a key task. Water for the canal comes in at series of inlet locks. Inlet Lock 1, which is at Lift Lock 5 over the Washington, DC boundary in Maryland, feeds the Georgetown section. Waste Weirs (a gate in the side of the canal) and the lift lock gates can be used used to adjust levels. There are also spillways along the canal, which are also referred to as "mule drinks" that operate like a dam spillway to let water flow out of canal if it is getting to close to the towpath level. Managing a water canal was challenging in 1850 and still is today.
audioDescription:
(179 words)
The C&O Canal Mule drink and overflow is located along the C&O Canal towpath in Washington, DC, about one-half mile south of Mile 2 on the towpath.
At this location the towpath divides. On the east side, the path becomes four-feet wide cement, and declines about one foot. It runs for about seventy-five feet before inclining again back to the level of the gravel towpath. The cement is lined with ridges at the incline and decline points.
On the west side, the path leads to a wood walkway with three-foot high wood rails on both sides. The walkway is supported by seven cement columns that allow for about three feet of space underneath. A one-foot wide cement border lines the east side of the cement path. Further east the ground slopes down slightly about five feet towards the canal.
West of the wooden walkway, the ground underneath is an approximately ten-foot wide strip of cobblestone that appears to run most of the seventy-five-foot length of the walkway. Trees and vegetation cover much of the west side of the path.
END OF DESCRIPTION

There were outtake pipes that were used to blow off steam from the boilers. Early on the morning of September 11, 2016, the Spong family was moored to the concrete wall theat ran beneath the powerhouse, right at a steam pipe. At usual time, 6 am, the powerhouse blew out the boilers and the steam burst and forc

images.altText: A building next to a reflective stream of water
images.title: C&O Canal Outtake
images.caption: C&O Canal Outtake

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText: Georgetown was once an industrial area. The building across the canal is the former Capital Traction Powerhouse, which provided power for the streetcars in Georgetown. There were outtake pipes that were used to blow off steam from the boilers. Early on the morning of September 11, 2016, the Spong family was moored to the concrete wall theat ran beneath the powerhouse, right at a steam pipe. At usual time, 6 am, the powerhouse blew out the boilers and the steam burst and forced super hot steam into the cabin of the boat where the children were sleeping. Mrs. Spong tried to save them and was severely scalded. Mr. Spong also rushed to save his children. Tragically, all three children, John (age 13,) Samuel (age 11,) and Sarah (age 6) were fatally injured.
audioDescription:
(241 words)
The C&O Canal Outtake is located west of Wisconsin avenue, NW along the C&O Canal in the Georgetown neighborhood in Washington, DC.
From the intersection of M street and Wisconsin avenue NW, travel south on Wisconsin avenue about two hundred seventy-five feet. Turn right, before the bridge overpass, and proceed about one hundred feet through a brick plaza area. A staircase leading down will be on the left. Follow the staircase and turn right at the towpath. Proceed about two hundred feet and you will be at the C&O Canal Outtake.
The canal is overgrown with tall grass at this location. Shallow water gently flows through the grass and reeds. The north side of the canal towpath is bordered by a seventy-foot tall stone wall. Across the canal is the red brick side of a two-story building. Along the bottom of the building is an old stone foundation about three feet tall. Set in the foundation is a round open pipe, about one-foot wide, curved to face downward two feet above the water line. A second opening sits one foot to the left. Ivy grows up the side of the brick building.
To the east, the Wisconsin avenue bridge is visible a few hundred yards away, running about forty feet above. The 31st street bridge sits one block beyond. To the west about two hundred feet, a pedestrian walkway connects to the second-floor level of the brick building across the canal.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: C&O Canal Spillway
listingDescription: The spill way is used to let high water in the canal flow back into the Potomac River. The spillway is also known as a "mule drink" as it is a low and convenient place for the canal mules to have a drink of water.

images.altText: A dirt road sits next to the C&O Canal
images.title: C & O Canal Spillway
images.caption: C & O Canal Spillway

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText: The spill way is used to let high water in the canal flow back into the Potomac River. The spillway is also known as a "mule drink" as it is a low and convenient place for the canal mules to have a drink of water.
audioDescription:
(145 words)
The C&O Canal Spillway is located along the C&O Canal towpath, about fifty feet south from the C&O Canal Mile 4 marker.
The Spillway is a section of the towpath that turns into a flat cement surface, consistent with the width and level of the towpath. The spillway slopes on both sides - towards the canal on the east side, and to the west towards the Potomac River. The Spillway spans about four hundred feet from north to south.
The towpath bows out to a wooden side section to the west and runs beside the cement Spillway. The side walkway is raised by two-foot tall cement pillars below that allow for overflow water from the canal to pass underneath. The walkway also spans about four hundred feet and features three-foot tall wood railings throughout on both sides. Trees line the walkway on its west side.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: C&O Canal Tidelock
listingDescription: Coal boats navigating the C&O Canal could use the tidelock to lock through between the Potomac River and Rock Creek, The used the last 1/4 of mile of the creek. Canal boats could then be taken nearby wharf or down river to unload at a power plant or warehouse along the Potomac. A dam with a waste gate went across the mouth of Rock Creek and was used to maintain a steady water level in Rock Creek for canal operations instead of having the creek get lower with a low tide. Ther

images.altText: A stone structure next to a river.
images.title: C&O Canal Tidelock
images.caption: C&O Canal Tidelock

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText: Coal boats navigating the C&O Canal could use the tidelock to lock through between the Potomac River and Rock Creek, The used the last 1/4 of mile of the creek. Canal boats could then be taken nearby wharf or down river to unload at a power plant or warehouse along the Potomac. A dam with a waste gate went across the mouth of Rock Creek and was used to maintain a steady water level in Rock Creek for canal operations instead of having the creek get lower with a low tide. There was a connector canal to the Washington City Canal that once existed where Constitution Ave is today.
audioDescription:
(427 words)
The C&O Canal Tide Lock wayside is located at the end of a peninsula formed by the Potomac River and Rock Creek in the Georgetown neighborhood of Washington, D.C.
From the intersection of Virginia Avenue and Rock Creek Parkway, NW travel west on Virginia avenue into a parking lot. Continue west through the parking lot, which will turn into a walkway bridge of about ninety feet over Rock Creek. Follow the path about eighty feet, at which point it will turn left. The Potomac River now will be on the right. Continue south and travel two hundred feet, past a cement landing at Thompson Boat Center on the left. Proceed through this area onto a gravel patch and continue another fifty feet. At this point the Potomac River edge will be approaching. Turn left and proceed fifty feet along a two-foot wide gravel path. The wayside will be on your right.
The wayside faces south and is set among the ruins of an old canal lock. A wooden pedestrian bridge is ten feet to the left, and a twenty-foot patch of overgrown grass sits between the sign and the lock ruins.
The three by four-foot sign is a faded light brown. Written across the top brown border is:
Tide Lock and Rock Creek Basin
Text across the top of the image reads:
The 184.5-mile-long Chesapeake and Ohio Canal begins at Tide Lock and ends at Cumberland, Maryland. Here canal boats entered the canal to bypass mountains, swift currents, and shallows. Boats exited Tide Lock into the Potomac River to proceed to downstream ports to off-load cargo.
A 200-foot dam (right side of photo below) crossed the mouth of Rock Creek, creating a basin where canal boats docked and off-loaded cargo.
A photograph covers the entire sign, showing a landscape of a bridge and a structure of wood beams carrying over a creek lined by stone walls. Two men stand with a horse on the left in the foreground. A small white building with one window sits at the end of the bridge, and other buildings can be see lining the background. The creek opens up to a river on the right.
A one by three-inch white map shows the Potomac River curling around the southern tip of Washington, DC.
Text to the left reads:
"Boats from Tide Lock could enter the Potomac River and go downstream to the Washington Branch Canal, where present-day Constitution Avenue is located. A lockhouse building still standing at 17th Street and Constitution Avenue is the only remaining evidence of this branch canal.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: C&O Canal Waste Weir
listingDescription: If the water level in the canal rose too high, paddles at the bottom of the gate could be opened to allow excess water to flow back into the Potomac.

bodyText: If the water level in the canal rose too high, paddles at the bottom of the gate could be opened to allow excess water to flow back into the Potomac.
audioDescription:
(165 words)
The C&O Canal Waste Weir is located along the C&O Canal towpath in Washington, DC, about one-half mile south of Mile 2 on the towpath and about eighty feet south of the C&O Canal mule drink and overflow.
At this location the towpath widens by about three feet and becomes a seventeen-foot long bridge with a wood plank floor. On the east side, six-foot tall cement walls angle out towards the canal. A three-foot tall wood railing guards the side.
A three-foot high rail also lines the west side. A seventeen-foot long wood beam is set in the ground about three feet from the west side of the path, creating a side path. Set atop the wood beam on the ground are three, three-foot tall black iron screws, each about two-inches thick and flat on top. They sit on an iron nut that is affixed to the beam with a metal bracket and bolts.
Trees, vegetation and brush line the west side of the path.
END OF DESCRIPTION

title: Catoctin Creek Aqueduct

images.altText: The three arch aqueduct spans a creek.
images.title: Catoctin Creek Aqueduct
images.caption: Catoctin Creek Aqueduct

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
The C&O Canal aqueducts are “water bridges” that carried canal boats over the creeks and rivers that flow into the Potomac River. Built in 1832, the Catoctin Aqueduct is the fourth of eleven such “works of art” on the canal.

The Catoctin Creek Aqueduct was known as the "Crooked Aqueduct" because canal boats had to make a sharp turn to cross it. From its original creation, the Catoctin Creek Aqueduct's structural integrity was questionable. The elliptical arch in the center was not as structurally sound as the semicircle arches on either side. The aqueduct began sagging in the early 1900s. It leaked and was prone to flooding. In 1973, two years after Congress established the C&O Canal National Historical Park, it collapsed, leaving only a small piece standing.

The Park Service gathered up the aqueduct’s stones and buried them with the hopes that someday the aqueduct would be restored. Nearly 35 years later, a restoration project gained enough funding to rebuild. The four hundred and fifty-nine stones where uncovered and the engineering crew began to fit the blocks together like a giant 3-demensional puzzle. Each stone was measured, and the crew used those measurements to create foam stones. Historic photos were then used to identify where individual stones were positioned. Missing stones or those in poor condition were replaced. In a little over a year, construction was complete. Today, new viewing areas and waysides allow visitors to learn about the structure and the efforts to rebuild it.
audioDescription: (268 words) Catoctin Aqueduct is located along the towpath in Jefferson, Maryland. It is 92 feet long with a three-arch construction. This aqueduct has an elliptical center arch with two semicircle arches on either side of the center arch. The top of the aqueduct has a water way for the canal boats and a towpath for the mules. The waterway of the aqueduct is about 15 feet wide and its bottom is about six feet lower than the towpath. To get to the aqueduct start from the Lock 29 (Lander) parking lot. Head Northwest from the parking lot to reach the road you drove in on. On the road, head Southwest, about 80 feet, or until you reach the wooden bridge. The pedestrian bridge crosses the middle of lock 29 and has two wooden railings. Continue past the lock to where the towpath intersects with the road, about 10 feet past the lock. Turn right onto the towpath and continue six tenths of a mile until the path forks. To the right is access to the aqueduct waterway. To the left is access to the aqueduct towpath. The waterway sits about six feet lower than the towpath. Select a path and walk another 350 feet to the aqueduct. On the waterway path you can see stone blocks forming walls on either side of you that are about 6 feet tall. On the towpath you can look down into the waterway on your right or look to the left at the river. The towpath has a fence on the river side and two-foot bumpers on the waterway side.

title: Clara Barton Home and Red Cross Headquarters
listingDescription: Clara Barton dedicated her life and energies to help others in times of need - both home and abroad, in peacetime as well as during military emergencies. Glen Echo was her home the last 15 years of her life and the structure illustrates her dedication and concern for those less fortunate than herself.

images.altText: A historic 3-story house with stone turrets on the corners with pointed caps.
images.title: Clara Barton Home (2023)
images.caption: Clara Barton Home

bodyText:
Over the course of her lifetime, Clara Barton was a dedicated Civil War nurse, an active women’s rights suffragette, and the founder and first president of the American Red Cross. She lived in the house on the property for a brief time in 1891, and then again from 1897 until her death in 1912. 

From 1891-97, the house served as an American Red Cross warehouse, and it was the organization’s national headquarters from 1897-1904. The Red Cross continued to use the house as a warehouse for relief supplies, stationery, and Red Cross publications. 

Inside, the first floor includes a parlor room, dining room, offices, and a kitchen. The second floor was for bedrooms, including Ms. Barton's room at the rear of the house. Look up to the third floor and note the windows with red crosses in them. Some of the interior walls and ceilings are covered with muslin, the same material used in bandages.

During her residence here, Barton developed the landscape into a miniature farm that was primarily self-sustaining, including crops, stables, and a chicken coop. This agricultural use of the landscape is no longer evident; development at the Glen Echo amusement park including roller coasters and the modern parking lot built over most of the farming operation. Many of the trees and plants that grow today are not consistent with the historic function of the grounds. However, the Clara Barton House is the most significant building associated with her time at Glen Echo, and it remains intact.

In the years following Ms. Barton's death in 1912, her colleague, Dr. Julian Hubbell, replaced the porch with a columned, one-story porch. His twin nieces inherited the house in 1929 and converted the interior to rent-producing apartments, added baths and kitchens, and a garage with screened porches above at the western rear corner. 

Congress declared the Clara Barton House a National Historic Landmark on January 12, 1965, and in 1974 passed legislation establishing the house and grounds as the Clara Barton National Historic Site. This property was acquired by NPS in April 1975 through a donation from the Friends of Clara Barton.
audioDescription: A three-story house with stone facades on either side and a peaked facade in the center. The ramp to access the front porch is to the left of the entrance via a front porch with white columns.

title: Coastal Plain
listingDescription: Learn about the geology of Prince William Forest Park by hiking the Quantico Cascades trail and exploring the area where the rolling hills of the Piedmont forest meets the flat, sandy coastal plain sediments.

images.altText: Slanted sign at the edge of the trail overlooks the creek in an open green forest
images.title: Coastal Plain Sign
images.caption: Learn about the coastal plain

bodyText: Why does the landscape flatten out here? As the Piedmont hills transition into the coastal plain on the eastern edge of Prince William Forest Park, the soil becomes sandier, the hills become gentler, and creeks widen as they flow towards the Potomac River. Standing beside Quantico Creek here, you can notice the sandy silt and small river rocks; quite a difference from the large rocks that stretch the length of the creek just upstream.
audioDescription: The trail follows Quantico Creek, a shallow stream about 10 feet in width. This stop is located in a flat, shaded area in the forest beside the creek. The sign has a black bar at the top with the words "National Park Service, U.S. Department of the Interior" and an NPS arrowhead symbol on the black bar in the upper right corner. The sign is titled "Coastal Plain" and a picture of shallow water flowing over gravel underlies the entire sign. Under the title in the upper left corner of the sign is a short paragraph reading, "As you walk along the trail, notice that the soil is becoming sandy to your right. You are now entering the Coastal Plain, a relatively flat area consisting of an accumulation of sediments washed down from the uplands and mountains. The Coastal Plain is actually a section of the Atlantic continental shelf that is no longer covered by the ocean." On the upper right corner of the sign next to the paragraph is a square image of the entire park map which is a large oval-like area of green with the two branches of Quantico Creek and major roadways and trails in the park. A circular enhanced portion of the map is to right of the square map image on the sign. This enhanced circular image shows the mapped waterway of Quantico Creek where you are currently standing. While the creek has tight curves near the top of the enhanced image (in the Piedmont), the curves start to straighten near the bottom of the enhanced image (in the Coastal Plain). A caption of the map image on the sign reads, "Remnants of hard upland rock force the waters of Quantico Creek to meander around them."

title: Conococheague Aqueduct

images.altText: A small boat passes through the aqueduct.
images.title: Conococheague Aqueduct
images.caption: The first boat through the restored Conococheague Aqueduct.

relatedParks.fullName: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park
relatedParks.name: Chesapeake & Ohio Canal

bodyText:
C&O Canal aqueducts are "water bridges" that carry canal boats over creeks and rivers that flow into the Potomac River. Built from 1833 to 1835, the Conococheague Aqueduct is the fifth of eleven such "works of art" on the canal. It consists of three equal 60' arch spans extending 196' between abutments.

In August 1863, Confederate soldiers damaged the Conococheague Aqueduct in an effort to stop the canal's transportation of coal to Georgetown where it was used by the Union. Repairs took four days and the canal returned to operation. In April 1920, a canal boat broke through the upstream wall of the aqueduct, falling into the creek below. This shut down the canal for over four months. Repaired with a timber wall, this version of the aqueduct functioned until two 1924 floods closed the canal for good.

In 2019, the NPS completed restoration of the Conococheague Aqueduct, reopening this exciting feature on the C&O Canal. The restored Conococheague Aqueduct provides a watered section of the canal to allow for canal boat operations and other public uses between Lock 44 and approximately 450 feet upstream of the existing aqueduct (approx. 0.70 miles). The $10.2 million project took two years to complete, and was funded through federal, state, local and private dollars including national park entrance fees and Maryland's Transportation Alternatives and Bikeways programs. 

Williamsport is now the only place in North America where visitors can view a variety of canal features in one place, including an operational lift lock and refurbished lockhouse, a railroad lift bridge, a canal turning basin and warehouse, and now a watered aqueduct. 


Conococheague Aqueduct Restored 

The National Park Service would like to acknowledge and thank those involved for their support with this projects. Please click here for a full Recognition of Support list.

 

Partner Organizations

The Town of Williamsport, Md.

Maryland Department of Transportation

Visit Hagerstown & Washington County

 

Frequently Asked Questions


How long did the project take to complete? 
The project began August of 2017 and was completed August 2019. 

What did the project include? 
The project included constructing cofferdams within Conococheague Creek and rebuilding the aqueduct piers; rebuilding and lining the aqueduct prism so that it is safe, sustainable, and watertight; repairs to the stone work; installation of a period-appropriate guardrail; clearing the canal prism upstream including constructing a berm; and removal of the existing berm on the downstream side so that entire stretch could be re-watered. 

How does this project benefit park visitors? 
Completion of this project provides park visitors an opportunity to experience a watered transportation canal aqueduct. The project also restores a significant historic resource and provides unique opportunities for visitors. 

How can I access the towpath at the Williamsport Visitor Center?
Pedestrians and cyclists are able to cross the canal at the historic railroad lift bridge (adjacent to Rt. 11). Parking is still available by the Cushwa Warehouse. 

What is the railroad lift bridge? 
Originally used to allow trains to cross the canal, visitors are now able to cross the bridge on a newly constructed stairway, which includes a low bike rail. (This is a great spot to get a view of the canal and aqueduct!). 

Where can I find accessible parking near the towpath?

Parking is also available close to the towpath at Lockhouse 44 parking lot and from the Bollman Bridge at River Bottom Park. These are the best access points for visitors with bike trailers, strollers, or wheelchairs. Dam 5 is the next closest location along the towpath that also has parking. 

Who can I contact if I have further questions regarding the restoration? 
For more information, please contact the C&O Canal Williamsport Visitor Center by calling 301-582-0813.
audioDescription: (153 words) The Conococheague Aqueduct is located along the towpath in Williamsport, Maryland. It has three, 60-foot arches and is 168 feet long. The top of the aqueduct has a water way for canal boats and a towpath for mules. The waterway of the aqueduct is about 12 feet wide and its bottom is about six feet lower than the towpath. To get to the Conococheague Aqueduct, start at the Railroad Lift Bridge. Cross over the bridge to the towpath. Turn right (Northwest) onto the towpath and walk one-tenth of a mile to the aqueduct. Once on the aqueduct you will be walking on the elevated towpath. On your right, the canal waterway sits about six feet lower than the towpath. There is no barrier between the towpath and the drop. On your left you can see Conococheague creek flowing into the Potomac River. There is a metal rail between the towpath and the river.

title: Counterscarp Gallery

images.altText: A brick structure with a slate roof. The arched doorway is partially blocked by wooden planks
images.title: Counterscarp gallery
images.caption: The counterscarp gallery under the weight of a fallen tree

bodyText:
Enemy soldiers landing at Piscataway Creek would need to contend with this position. In what is basically a bunker, defending soldiers could direct small arms, like rifles, towards an approaching foe. If enemy troops managed to breach the outer defenses, fire could also be reversed and directed towards the outer lying dry moat. 

The Counterscarp Gallery is in poor condition. Please exercise caution around the site.
audioDescription: The Counterscarp Gallery is an L- shaped defensive structure that is approximately 50 feet in length, and is made up of red bricks and stone with a black slate shingled roof. The interior of the L-shaped structure is hollow on the inside resembling a tunnel, and was used as a reinforced firing position for the rear defenses of Fort Washington.
